title: Mazda bucks the trend at Tokyo Motor Show
text:
Tony Davis Motoring Writer Oct 30, 2019 — 11.37am Share

The most popular vehicle at this year’s Tokyo Motor Show, the event once considered the biggest signpost to the automotive future? The mobility scooter.

Almost every Japanese maker is presenting solutions for the aged and infirm. There are sit-on scooters galore, plus powered wheelchairs, self-righting “walkers”, home assistant robots and various concept cars designed to highlight how automation will benefit those who can’t, or no longer wish to, hold a steering wheel.

"We are confident you will see the car on Australian roads," says Mazda Australia's Alastair Doak.

The demographics tell it all. Twenty-eight per cent of Japanese citizens are over 65 years old, and the population is shrinking as dramatically as it is ageing. There will be fewer and fewer young people to look after the swelling ranks of the elderly.

The car show itself is also shrinking, as are almost all others. Most foreign makers have stayed away from Tokyo and most cars on display are micros aimed at the domestic market.

Exceptions include the Lexus LF-30 concept and a near-production ready electric SUV from Mazda. Known as the MX-30, it has a fastback roof, and reverse opening rear doors like a Mazda RX-8 or BMW i3. Mazda has confirmed few details beyond the fact the MX-30 will go on sale in Europe next year, and could come to Australia after that.

The interior of the MX-30. No specs are available yet.

“It is very much on our wish list,” says Mazda Australia marketing director Alastair Doak “and we are very confident you will see it on Australian roads – probably in 2021.”

Although there is no indication yet of pricing, it will be most likely be an expensive niche model.

At September’s Frankfurt Motor Show, attendance numbers were down 30 per cent on the previous show (2017) and more than 40 per cent on 2015. Many in the industry have pointed out that such shows are no longer the most cost-effective way of connecting with consumers, nor the best way for consumers to gain all the details on the latest new models.

Also on show in Tokyo: Suzuki's Kupo can be used as a cart for shopping or as an electric wheelchair.

Tellingly, VW has just unveiled its eighth-series Golf, yet chose not display it at either Frankfurt or Tokyo.

Can the world’s few remaining major car shows survive? Watch this space.
description: The car maker has unveiled a sporty-looking electric SUV that will make its debut in Europe next year.
